The  growth  potential  of  the  urban  sector  in  Bangladesh  is  severely 
undermined by frequent flooding. There are about 550 urban centers 
in  Bangladesh  and  many  of  them  suffer  from  severe  erosion  and   
destruction of  physical infrastructure  caused by  river flooding  and  
waterlogging.    Flooding    is    a    perennial    problem    and  the  urban

high  population  density  and  concentration      of      industrial      and     
investments  sites.    While  the Government had wanted to address 
the  problems  of  flooding  and  erosion  in  urban  areas  as  early  as  in 
the  1970s,  no  major  investments  could  be  carried  out  due  to 
resource  constraints.  As  a  result,  the  urban  areas,  especially  the 
secondary towns, have remained neglected. 
 
After the devastating floods of 1987 and 1988, the Government and 
development  partners  prepared  the  Flood  Action  Plan.  Under  the 
plan,  Dhaka  and  15  district  towns  were  identified  for  urban  flood 
protection. ADB has already provided two loans to cover Dhaka and 
6  of  the  15  district  towns.  ADB's  intervention  proved  to  be  very 
effective, as evidenced during another massive flooding in 1998. The 
proposed Project will cover the remaining towns identified earlier. A 
feasibility study for a third loan for urban flood protection is included 
under the Project.

1. 

Urban Flood Protection in Bangladesh 

However, frequent flooding severely undermines the growth potential of the urban sector.   

 
Although  the  level  of  urbanization  in  Bangladesh  is  relatively  low  with  23%  of  the 
3. 
population  residing  in  urban  areas,  already  over  40%  of  the  country’s  gross  domestic  product 
(GDP)––from a low of 25% in the early 1970s––is derived from the urban sector. The role of the 
urban  centers  as  the  engine  of  growth  is  clearly  recognized  in  the  Government’s  latest  5-year 
plan documents, which projected that the urban sector GDP would grow at more than twice the 
rate of the national GDP.  
 
4. 
There are about 550 urban centers in Bangladesh and many of them suffer from severe erosion 
and destruction of physical infrastructure because of river flooding and water-logging. Flooding is 
a perennial problem in Bangladesh and the urban areas are more prone to economic and human 
losses due to their high population density and concentration of industrial and investment sites. 
While  the  Government  had  wanted  to  address  the  problems  of  flooding  and  erosion  in  urban 
areas  as  early  as  in  the  1970s,  no  concerted  major  investments  could  be  carried  out  due  to 
resource  constraints.  As  a  result,  the  urban  areas,  especially  the  secondary  towns,  remained 
neglected.  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  Bangladesh  highlights  the  strategic 
importance  of  secondary  towns  in  the  urbanization  process,  and  the  need  to  promote  them  to 
lead  a  sound  and  balanced  urban  development.  The  Government's  Interim-Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy  Paper  (I-PRSP)1 also recognizes urban local bodies as one of the key instruments for 
ensuring  improved  quality  and  enhanced  accountability  of  public  service  in  urban  areas.  The  I-
PRSP  strongly  supports  capacity  building  at  the  local  level,  including  effective  participation  of 
women in local governance. As for flood protection, reduction of vulnerability to natural disaster is 
recognized as an integral aspect of the national strategy for poverty reduction. 
 
The  devastating  floods  of  1987  and  1988  were  a  reminder  to  all  concerned,  including 
5. 
policy  makers  and  external  development  partners,  that  the  threats  of  severe  flooding  could  no 
longer  be  left  unattended  (Appendix  2).  A  strong  consensus  was  formed  quickly  for  immediate 
action  in  a  concerted  manner.  A  year  later,  the  Government  and  the  international  community 
together formulated a comprehensive program, called the Flood Action Plan (FAP), to develop a 
sustained  solution  to  the  dangers  of  frequent  flooding.  The  FAP  comprised  26  activities  for 
physical  investments,  technical  studies,  and  support  activities.  For  urban  flood  protection,  the 
FAP  identified  Dhaka  and  15  district  towns  to  be  supported  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank

6. 
Prior  to  the  ADB  investments,  the  earlier  interventions  related  to  urban  flood  protection 
remained largely at master planning stage. Where actual investments were carried out, they were 
implemented  by  various  agencies  on  an  ad  hoc  basis  without  proper  coordination.  In  fact, 
piecemeal efforts had generally been ineffective and, in some cases, inadvertently compounded 
the  environmental  health  hazards.  Inadequate  drainage  resulted  in  polluted  waters  remaining 
stagnant in low-lying land (often densely populated slum areas) for long periods. Uncoordinated 
collection  and  disposal  of  solid  waste  contributed  to  localized  flooding  due  to  clogged  drains. 
Similarly,  inadequate  and  ineffective  excreta  management  led  to  high  levels  of  exposure  to 
waterborne  pathogens  during  floods.  A  clear,  urgent  need  thus  emerged  to  integrate  flood 
protection  works  with  other  infrastructure  and  environment  improvement  measures  in  selected 
high-priority  secondary  towns  to  maximize  impact.  Given  such  experience,  ADB  adopted  an 
integrated approach where flood protection was combined with drainage, sanitation, solid waste 
management, and slum development in one project. 
 
7. 
Although  implementation  of  ADB’s  integrated  flood  protection  project  for  the  six  district 
towns  was  delayed  by  2  years  due  to  unforeseen  natural  causes  and  political  events,  flood 
protection  facilities  constructed  under  it  have  safely  withstood  annual  flood  seasons  since  then. 
Moreover,  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  reports  confirmed  that  the  total  beneficiaries 
exceeded  the  targets  set  during  project  appraisal.  The  respondents  in  both  slum  and  non-slum 
areas  cited  significant  direct  benefits  from  reduced  flood  damage,  including  improved  hygiene 
and a cleaner environment, and more efficient solid waste collection. Substantial indirect benefits 
were also reported: better housing, higher land values, increased daily incomes, and reduction in 
illness  and  medical  costs.  The  project  also  provided  significant  construction  employment 
opportunities  for  the  local  poor,  and  livelihood  skills  training  for  women-led  community-based 
handicraft industries. With this positive feedback, the Government and ADB agreed to complete 
the flood protection facilities for the remaining nine towns that were left out from the first phase of 
the project.

Analysis of Lessons Learned from Phase 1 

The preparation of the phase 2 of the Project is firmly based on the lessons learned from 
12. 
phase 1.4 While many documents and reports have been prepared to fully or partially review the 
achievements  of  phase  1,  project  completion  reports  and  the  project  performance  audit  report 
(PPAR)5 are particularly important. The project preparatory TA also carried out a separate review 
and  consolidated  all  the  lessons  learned  to  incorporate  them  in  the  design  of  the  new  Project. 
While  the  Project  is  not  perceived  as  disaster  related,  it  has  significant  disaster  mitigating 
implications. The Project will help reduce the incidence of future disaster related to flooding and 
lessen the demand for rehabilitation projects after disaster. As such, the design of the Project is in 
compliance with ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy, 2004.6  
 
13. 
ADB’s  PPAR  by  the  Operations  Evaluation  Department  confirms  that  phase  1  of  the 
Project  has  achieved  its  main  objective.  Since  project  completion,  the  six  towns  have  been 
protected  from  annual  floods.  Drainage  and  sanitation  facilities  have  reduced  the  incidence  of 
waterborne  diseases.  Improvements  in  the  living  environment  as  a  consequence  of  the  project 
were recognized by the majority of the respondents in all project towns. The slum improvement 
component  directly  benefited  some  8,000  households  and  provided  a  greater sense of security 
and permanence within towns.

capacity  building  in  financial  management.  Considerable  problems  also  persisted  with  the

Component B: Urban Drainage System Improvement

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IM PACTS, AND RISKS 

 
A. 
 

Major Benefits and Impacts 

1. 

Social and Gender Aspects 

 
68. 
Poverty incidence was as high as 40% of the sample households, where income is below 
the poverty line of Tk44,410 per year ($65 per month). Households in hard core poverty survive 
on  incomes  of  less  than  Tk36,345  per  year  ($53  per  month),  concentrate  in  overcrowded  slum 
and  squatter  areas,  and  lead  a  hand-to-mouth  existence.  Between  7%  and  30%  of  the 
households in hard core poverty are headed by women (Appendix 11). Focus group discussions 
strongly underline the appeal of the poor for employment opportunities and decent wages; their 
emphasis is on the need to improve drainage for quicker clearance of rainwater and facilitation of 
normal  movement  during  flooding  to  mitigate  the  loss  of  workdays.  Women  are  particularly 
concerned about shelter for themselves and their animals, children’s access to schools, as well 
as  access  to  medicine  and  health  care,  especially  during  floods.  Poverty  reduction  has  been 
made as a strategic objective of each Project component, with the view to maximize employment 
during  construction,  develop  skills  for  O&M,  and  make  roads  and  basic  services  available  in 
deprived  areas.  In  slums,  improved  access  to  water  supply,  sanitation,  solid  waste  disposal, 
roads and footpaths, lighting, schools and health care will be assured. To this end each town will 
have  its  own  PRAP  and  GAP,  which  will  be  prepared  with  primary  stakeholder  participation,  in 
response to expressed needs.12

weak  implementation  of  the  subproject  at  the  town  level,  (iii)  inadequate  coordination  between

facilities and services provided under the Project.

THE WATER SECTOR IN BANGLADESH 

Institutional Development 

Milestone Events in the Water Sector 

 
A. 
 
After the creation of Pakistan in 1947, the provincial Irrigation Directorate was in charge 
1. 
of  the  development  of  water  resources  and  flood  control  facilities.  Following  the  devastating 
floods of 1954 and 1955, a United Nation (UN) mission—the Krug Mission— recommended the 
creation  of  the  East  Pakistan  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  (EPWAPDA).  This  was 
established  in  1959  with  two  wings:  Water  Wing  and  Power  Wing.  The  Water  Wing  was 
restructured in 1972 as Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) and its mandate limited 
to  water  resources  development.  BWDB  was  reconstituted  in  July  2000  under  a  new  Act  that 
repositions the organization and aligns its responsibilities to those set out in the National Water 
Policy (NWP).   
 
B. 
 
The  Water  Wing  of  EPWAPDA  prepared  a  master  plan  envisaging  58  massive  flood 
2. 
control  and  drainage  (FCD)  projects  and  three  barrages  on  three  major  rivers.  Projects 
implemented  by  EPWAPDA  covered  mainly  the  engineering  aspects  to  help  boost  agricultural 
production to meet the country’s demand. It was claimed that the master plan ignored the needs 
of  nonagricultural  water-using  sectors.  A  World  Bank  study  in  1972  suggested  a  major  shift  in 
strategy from massive FCD projects to minor irrigation complemented by agricultural input supply 
and support services. The World Bank Mission recommended a review of BWDB activities and 
stressed the creation of a planning body outside BWDB to prepare a NWP that emphasizes on 
maximizing agricultural growth and production for food grain self-sufficiency. The NWP that was 
prepared put heavy reliance on minor irrigation through massive fielding of tube wells and low-lift 
pumps utilizing available surface water from rivers and other water resources. 
 
The  country  experienced  two  consecutive  massive  floods  in  1987  and  1988,  which 
3. 
prompted the government to undertake immediate rehabilitation works, and in parallel a few joint 
studies.  Later  a  flood  action  plan  (FAP)  consisting  of  26  studies  and  pilot  projects  was 
undertaken  with  the  support  of  various  sources.  The  major  achievement  of  the  FAP  was  the 
preparation of five regional studies and three important guidelines for: (i) project assessment, (ii) 
people’s participation, and (iii) environmental impact assessment. At the conclusion of the FAP 
studies the Bangladesh flood and management strategy was produced as the final report of the 
FAP. The report outlined a strategic framework for developing and implementing a national water 
management system and formulating a NWP and national water management plan (NWMP). It is 
worth mentioning that the NWP was prepared and approved by the Government in 1999, while 
the  NWMP  was  approved  by  the  Government  on  31  March  2004.  The  Secondary  Towns 
Integrated Flood Protection Project-II (STIFPP-II) is being formulated under the umbrella of the 
FAP. The NWMP provides the overall approach to and program for future urban flood protection, 
but actual formulation of the investment plans will be the responsibility of the end users. 
 
4. 
The  FAP  was  instrumental  in  bringing  a  paradigm  shift  in  water  planning  methodology, 
putting  emphasis  on  equal  rights  of  all  water  users  and  mandatory  use  of  environment  impact 
assessment  (EIA)  and  guidelines  for  people's  participation  at  all  stages  of  the  project  cycle 
(planning,  design,  implementation,  and  operation  and  maintenance).  In  line  with  the  above 
policies  and  with  the  changing  demand,  the  role  of  BWDB  has  been  redefined  and  a  new 
management structure is in place through reforms and downsizing of its manpower.

incorporate  the  mechanism  for  establishing  and  operationalizing  beneficiary  organizations  like

approved  by  the  Government  on  31  March  2004.  Even  before  approval,  the  salient  features  of 
the NWMP were incorporated in the Government's Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper.  
 
7.

it  fully  autonomous  with  an  independent  governing  council,  separating  management  from  the

it  is  possible  that  most  of  the  actions  associated  with  the  reform  process  will  have  been

objective is to promote a sense of ownership among beneficiaries and their willingness to share 
the  cost  of  maintenance  that  would  eventually  relieve  BWDB  of  the  O&M  burden. Progress is 
slow on this.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
Despite the high incidence of natural disasters and many adverse conditions, Bangladesh has achieved considerable 
progress over the years in reducing both income and human poverty. Absolute poverty dropped from 58.7% in 1991 to 
49.8% of the population in 2000.1 The declining trend is valid for both rural and urban poverty, the latter having fallen 
from 44.9% (1991) to 36.6% (2000). Whereas progress in reducing the head count index of poverty was better in the 
urban areas,  rural  areas  fared  better  in  reducing  the  severity  of  poverty  as  captured  by  trends  in  poverty  gap  and 
squared poverty gap. The uneven reduction in urban poverty is explained by the greater urban income inequality, as 
the Gini coefficient increased by 2.3% per year, from 0.307 to 0.368 over the period.  
 
The principal reason behind this phenomenon is the steady migration of the resource poor from rural to urban areas in 
search  of  employment  and  better  economic  opportunities.  Migration  inflates  the  annual  growth  rate  of  the  urban 
population and triggers the sprouting shanty settlements along the towns’ river embankments or in surrounding low-
lying  areas.  In  some  towns  considered  under  Secondary  Towns  Integrated  Flood  Protection  Phase  II  (STIFPP-II), 
such settlements represent more than 25% of the population. The towns are prone to flooding and river erosion, and 
the poorer income groups, especially recently settled women dwellers, are very vulnerable to disaster. Lack of flood 
protection  and  inadequate  drainage  lead  to  waterlogging  and  overflowing  of  sewers,  causing  widespread 
environmental degradation and deplorable unsanitary living conditions, particularly in slums and squatter areas.   
 
Urban development is important in reducing the vulnerability of the urban poor and contributes to a safer, less morbid 
living  environment  for  them  throughout  the  year.  The  provision  of  flood  protection  infrastructure,  drainage,  slum 
improvement,  and  capacity  assistance  for  improving  urban  governance  will  enable  the  poorer  groups,  men  and 
women, to benefit directly from employment created in construction and operation and maintenance (O&M), and from 
additional social programming around microcredit, income generation, and environmental improvement, all of which 
are indispensable to reduce poverty. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has already lent well over $300 million for 
six  urban  infrastructure  projects  since  it  began  its  operation  in  Bangladesh  in  the  late  1980s.  The  proposed 
intervention will significantly enhance the gains made so far in urban infrastructure and governance and in reducing 
poverty in the secondary towns of Bangladesh.

13. 
The  rates  and  charges  currently  used  by  municipalities  for  cost  recovery  are  not  all 
necessarily  appropriate  funding  mechanisms  for  recovery  of  incremental  O&M  costs.  The 
drainage  improvements  and  solid  waste  management  services  confer  a  specific  benefit  to 
individual  property  owners  as  well  as  a  general  benefit  to  all  community  members  within  the 
municipal  boundaries.  The  property  tax  is  a  broadly  based  local  tax  that  allocates  cost  to  tax 
payers in proportion to assessed property values. For this reason, the property tax is the best 
funding instrument for drainage maintenance and solid waste management services.  
 
14. 
The  first  step  toward  cost  recovery  is  tax  reform  involving  an  increase  in  collection 
efficiency and property assessments.  Efforts to update assessments and improve tax collection 
should be pursued first to realize the full potential of existing property taxes. These efforts will 
also reduce the implicit cross subsidy that now exists between people who pay their taxes and 
those who do not. With adequate promotion, this change can increase public acceptance of the 
property  tax  system  and  public  willingness  to  accept  future  tax  rate  increases.  The  following 
measures are proposed as a cost recovery strategy for municipal O&M costs: 

Improve  property  tax  collection  efficiency  and  update  property  assessments.  An 
overall  collection  efficiency  of  80%  and  a  20%  increase  in  assessment  are 
proposed as achievable targets by FY2009. 

Increase property tax rates as needed up to the maximum allowable thresholds to 
cover the remaining funding deficits by FY2009.  

Increase  other  user  fees  and  charges  as  a  last  resort  if  property  tax  rate 
adjustments do not generate sufficient revenue.

7. 
The  STIFPP  II  is  within  the  Asiatic  monsoon  region  in  Bangladesh.  The  area  is  humid

population and building density, paved areas, and reduced green space, urban runoff discharge 
has  increased  considerably,  often  rendering  existing  drainage  systems  inadequate.    While  the

unaccounted  for  poorer  income  groups,  notably  recently  settled  dwellers  who  are  most 
vulnerable to the impacts of flooding and inadequate drainage.

storage site selecting in areas with no topsoil (sandy areas) would be more appropriate.

concentration is not considered higher than that generated at present by river erosion and may 
be considered minor.

Intense  floods  can  last  for  2  months  of  the  year,  preventing  the  opening  of  gates  and

during  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA),  a  sanitation  and  wastewater 
treatment management plan will be formulated for each of the nine towns to suggest appropriate 
sanitation measures. 
 
24. 
As part of the mitigating  measures implemented in the solid waste management center, 
regular  pest  (rodents  and  insects)  treatment  will  be  carried  out.  Moreover,  an  OHSP  ensuring 
the  safety  and  good  health  of  the  operators  in  those  centers  will  be  formulated  and  endorsed 
before  starting operation.   
 
The  proposed  landfill  is  anticipated  to  produce  significant  amounts  of  gases,  e.g. 
25. 
methane  and  carbon  dioxide.  In  addition,  gases  like,  hydrogen  sulfide,  carbon  monoxide,  and 
ammonia may be formed in small quantities from decomposing solid waste. These are odorous 
gases and may create nuisance and health hazards to nearby communities if not controlled. In 
addition,  they  may  have  some  negative  effect  on  the  vegetation  of  the  area.  Mitigating 
measures  proposed  to  minimize  the  negative  impacts  include  provision  of  proper  soil  cover, 
buffer zone, planting, and a proper gas control system. The option to reuse methane as biogas 
for power production may also be considered at the detailed design stage.

to  minimize  gas  emissions  in  busy  areas,  provision  of  a  traffic  management  plan  and  close 
coordination between municipalities and traffic police personnel for smooth execution. 
 
27. 
The presence of silt and solid waste in drains may obstruct the flow, resulting in overflow 
or  flooding,  and  further  environmental  pollution  in  areas  along  the  drains.  Provision  must  be

the drains.
